content.description: Go up the center of the washboard boulder, sit start.

The logical start is on the right facing undercling crimp rail then moving into the next right facing side pull crimps before going to the "V" out left. From there you can either escape onto the slab to avoid to the high potentially chossy top out or do what appears to be another big move and the high top out.

 Let me know any info on name, grade, or FA and I can update the page. The line going straight up through two gaston crimps to a large edge looks cool but would require more pads and at least one spotter.
content.protection: At least three pads + spotter recommended
content.location: Overhang on the south of the Washington Boulder

content.description: Starts on a decent rail in front of a good jug (the only good jug inside the cave) the exit and top out are difficult so good padding and spotting is recommended. The moves are hard and somewhat painful but it's one of the best problems at the palisades.
content.location: This cave can be spotted from Washington boulder, inside you will find a wodden beam and some old towels.

content.description: Start on the rail as for Sick Cat Left. At the end of rail, stay low & move right into the start of Sick Cat Right. Finish as for that problem.
content.location: The second wall on the right of the wash, up & left from washboard.

content.description: Star sitting down under the roof with a left hand in the obvious pocket.  Work your way up the the very sharp crack shooting off to the right.  Follow this crack right and top out.
content.location: This climb is located on a boulder known as Item B about ten feet passed the Washboard Wall up and to your right.

content.description: Start on the rail deep into the left with both hands matching and a left heel hook.  The original start on the nob is loose and should not be used.  Throw right to the deep pocket and then use crimpers straight up to the top.  All big ledges in the center of the boulder are off route.
content.location: This route is located on Item B Boulder ten feet up and to the right of washboard.

content.description: A small but tricky cap-rock boulder problem.
content.location: Left (west) of the well known Apex Roof.

content.description: Sit start left hand on the lower protruding rock, right and in the pocket behind. Move up using the best crimps on the face. Very slabby. Looked like it's never been climbed before or at least not in years.
content.location: Right above apex roof next to two other established climbs (purple dragon juice?)

content.description: Start as low as possible with both has on the arete side.  A quick three moves up and around will finish this climb.  V-Fun for the extreme beginner or just someone who likes to climb on everything.
content.location: This climb is located right before the Apex roof.  You might walk by it without noticing.

content.description:
Sit down start under the mini roof, use a knee bar to start with bad hands.  Move your hands up to the obvious Rail center of face.  Work your left hand up to secret hold and slap your right up the edge to get a final foot on and top out.  

  All Orange colored rock is off and should not be used.  It is likely to break.  (  Eyes of the Iron Giant)
content.location: As you approach, walk past Washboard Boulder and Sick Cat Boulder.  As you come across Washington Boulder on your left, look up and right.  You will see a scramble through cacti and boulders, take this up and climb over the boulders to find a nice set of climbs  Irong Giant on left and two face climbs on right.

content.description: Start with your left hand on the gem hold and right hand on the crimp rail, move out left to the flake and then make a big move to the top.
content.location: Left of apex roof below the left cliff, slightly behind a small yucca

content.description: Start on parallel sidepulls and pull up in a scrunched posistion to a sharp crimp. The arete is off.
content.location: On the right side of the aroyo opposite of sick kids. To the right of a bp called iron giant.

content.description: Start sitting down with and initial reach to a good hold and work your way up the center of the face using crimpy holds.
content.location: This climb is a couple levels above the well known Apex Roof.

content.description: The right side of Apex Roof. This is V5 if you go back left from the start and use the center pocket before moving back to the right. It's probably ~V6 if you skip that pocket and stay right the whole time. Harder eliminates also exist.
More or less straight up Apex Roof
The farthest left line on Apex roof
content.location: The obvious short, steep wall in the middle of the wash about 2/3 of the way up the hill

content.description: Start the climb sitting down using the obvious rail.  Move to the pocket then work your way back to the right using small small crimpers until you get to the crack right before the top out.
content.location: This climb is located left of washboard while walking towards Apex Roof.  There is a very large obvious boulder called Washington Boulder about thirty feet passed washboard.  Walk up to the base and around to the left of it and the hill to find an obvious scoop.

content.description:
A small boulder choked arroyo located near the West entrance to Scenic Dr. Local mountain folks call the canyon Crazy Cat, but it's official name is The Palisades. A park sign is located at the trailhead with Rules and Information. 

  This area has a no recorded climbing history that I know of. Freinds and I started visiting the area in 1994. Most obvious boulder problems had already been established and the Prow had signs of previous climbers top roping its steep faces. 

  The Palisades is currently the only bouldering area in the Franklin Mountain range open to the public. So its become the spot for climbers to go get a quick fix and pump-out.
